data.query: How is Brazil currently performing on its national climate goals, and which policies are driving progress or falling behind?

modules.heading: Summary
texts: Brazil has established comprehensive institutional frameworks for climate governance, including the Interministerial Committee on Climate Change (CIM) that coordinates federal climate policy implementation across 23 ministries ^2^. However, the country faces significant challenges in meeting its climate goals, particularly regarding deforestation, where rates surged to approximately 10,851 kmÂ² in 2020 after initial progress from 2004-2012, undermining Brazil's NDC commitments to eliminate illegal deforestation by 2030 ^3^. ^4^

Brazil's climate governance operates through the Interministerial Committee on Climate Change (CIM), established by Decree 11.550/2023, which brings together 23 ministries under the leadership of the Chief of Staff of the Presidency ^2^. The CIM coordinates implementation of the National Policy on Climate Change, defines successive nationally determined contributions under the Paris Agreement, and approves sectoral mitigation and adaptation plans ^2^. The committee meets every six months and includes non-voting representatives from civil society, interfederative coordination, and scientific advisory bodies ^2^. ^5^

At the subnational level, states are developing their own climate frameworks. AmapÃ¡ enacted comprehensive climate legislation (State Law 3.128/2024) establishing mitigation objectives including forest conservation, bio-economy development, and renewable energy transition ^6^. MaranhÃ£o's State Policy on Climate Change (State Law 12.301/2024) requires development of sectoral mitigation and adaptation plans, disaster risk reduction strategies, and municipal climate policies ^7^. SÃ£o Paulo has developed PAC2050 with net-zero emissions goals by 2050 and is creating a State Plan for Climate Adaptation and Resilience (PEARC) focused on infrastructure resilience and vulnerable populations ^8^. ^9^

Brazil is developing a new Climate Plan (Plano Clima) that will include a National Adaptation Strategy with sixteen sectoral adaptation plans covering agriculture, biodiversity, cities, energy, health, and other key areas ^10^. The strategy establishes nine national adaptation objectives, including increasing resilience of populations and infrastructure, promoting food security, ensuring water security, and protecting ecosystems ^10^. This builds upon Brazil's existing 2016 National Adaptation Plan (PNA), which remains in effect while under review ^10^.

Climate change integration into national development planning is established in law and policy, though implementation details are not specified ^11^. The country has also enacted Federal Law 15.042/2024 establishing the Brazilian Greenhouse Gas Emissions Trading System (SBCE), which includes provisions for internationally transferred mitigation outcomes (ITMOs), though implementing regulations from CIM are still under development ^12^.

Brazil's energy sector policies include mandates for greenhouse gas emissions reduction in fuel commercialization through the RenovaBio program ^13^^14^. Recent amendments to environmental legislation have expanded mitigation requirements to include low-carbon hydrogen and derivatives alongside biofuels ^15^. The country's energy expansion scenario through the ten-year planning period is reported to meet and surpass 2020 targets and align with NDC commitments for the energy sector ^16^.

The transition to a low-carbon economy is explicitly referenced in policy documents as a key objective, emphasizing greenhouse gas reduction and preservation of natural carbon sinks ^17^. Transportation and energy sectors are specifically targeted for emissions mitigation through biofuels and other low-carbon alternatives ^15^^18^.

Brazil's climate performance faces significant challenges from deforestation patterns. The map shows deforestation point locations representing polygons of 100 hectares or larger, totaling approximately 1,278,455 hectares across 4,875 locations ^4^. Historical data reveals that while Brazil made substantial progress reducing deforestation from 2004-2012 through policies like the Amazon Fund, rates surged again from 2012-2020 ^3^.

This deforestation surge has led to increased carbon emissions that contradict Brazil's NDC commitments to eliminate illegal deforestation by 2030 ^3^. The effectiveness of climate policies is further complicated by governance challenges, including implementation difficulties with the National Policy for Payments for Environmental Services (PNPSA) due to legislative vetoes ^3^.

Brazil faces increasing climate extremes that significantly impact ecosystems and agriculture, with the IPCC expressing high confidence that climate change is exacerbating the frequency and intensity of droughts and floods ^19^. These climate impacts create additional challenges for meeting national climate goals and highlight the importance of the comprehensive adaptation planning currently under development ^20^.

metadata.title: PRODES deforestation point locations (â‰¥ 100 ha)
metadata.description: Each point marks the center of an INPE/PRODES deforestation polygon in Brazil that is at least 100 hectares. The dataset contains 4,875 polygons above this threshold; this map shows the top 4,875 by area.
